bio:treatment.discussion: Bucklandiella afoninae is the rarest species of the genus, known in the flora area only from a single site from western Alaska (Seaward Peninsula), which corresponds to several localities of the species in Chukotka in arctic Russia. Although it is known only in the barren state, it fits well into the concept of sect. Marginatae on account of its linear basal cells with strongly incrassate and porose longitudinal walls, and the presence of a distinct basal marginal border that is composed of exceptionally long, mostly linear cells. Such leaf border is unknown in any other species of the genus in the flora area. The other exceptional character of this species is spirally twisted leaves, and such leaf arrangement is known only in two austral species of Bucklandiella, B. emersa and B. rupestris.
